sp.l: And from me they shall be removables.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Item in the servants chamber, two pair of cursed queens tongues.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Tongs thou wouldst say.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay they pinch worse than tongs.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: They are movables I will warrant.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Item, one pair of horns in the bride chamber, on the beds head.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: The beasts head, for Motto is stuffed in the head, and these are among unmovable goods.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Well , Faeliix quem faciunt aliena pericula cautum, happy are they whom other men's horns do make to beware. Item, a broken pate owing me by one of the coal-house, for notching his head like a chessboard. Take thou that, and I give thee all the rest of his debts.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Noli me tangere, I refuse the executorship, because I will not meddle with his desperate debts. Item, an hundred shrewd turns owing me by the Pages in the Court, because I will not trust them for trimming.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: That is due debt.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well , because is Motto poor, they shall be paid him cum recumbentibus. All the Pages shall enter into recognisance, but ecce, Pipenetta chants it.

sp.l: Las how long shall I
And my Maidenhead lie
In a cold Bed all the night long,
I cannot abide it,
Yet away cannot chide it,
Though I find, it does me some wrong.
Can any one tell
Where this fine Thing doth dwell,
That carries nor form, nor fashion?
It both heats and cools,
It is a Bauble for Fools,
Yet caught at in every Nation.
Say a Maid were so crossed,
As to see this Toy lost,
Cannot Hue and Cry fetch it again?
Las! no, for it is driven
Nor to Hell, nor to Heaven,
When it is found, it is lost even then.
Hey ho, would I were a Witch, that I might be a Duchess.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I know not whether thy fortune is to be a Duchess, but sure I am thy face serves thee well for a Witch, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Pipe.
sp.p: The matter, marry it is proclaimed, that whosoever can tell the cause, and the Reeds Song, shall either have Sophronia to wife, or (if she refuse it) a Dukedom for his wisdom. Besides, whosoever saith, that Mydas hath Asses ears, shall lose theirs.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: I will be a Duke, I find honour to bud in my head, and methinks every joint of mine arms, from the shoulder to the little finger, says send for the Herald. Mine arms are all Armoury, Gules, Sables, Azure, Or, Vert, Pur, Post, Pare, etcetera.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And my heart is like a hearth where Cupid is making a fire, for Sophronia shall be my wife: methinks Venus and Nature stand with each of them a pair of bellows, the one cooling my low birth, the other kindling my lofty affections.

sp.speaker: Pipe.
sp.l: Apollo will help me, because I can sing.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Mercury me, because I can lie.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
All the Gods me, because I can lie, sing, swear, and love . But soft, here comes Motto, now shall we have
a fit time to be revenged, if by device we can make him say, Mydas hath Asses ears:

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p: Let us not seem to be angry about the Inventory, and you shall see my wit to be the Hangman for his tongue.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Why Fools, hath a Barber a tongue?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: We will make him have a tongue, that his teeth that look like a Comb, shall be the Scissors to cut it off.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: I pray let me have the odd ends. I fear nothing so much as to be tongue tied.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Thou shalt have all the shavings, and then a woman's tongue imped with a Barbers, will prove a Razor or a razor.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: How now Motto, what all amort?

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: I am as melancholy as a Cat.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p: Melancholy? marie gup, is melancholy a word for a Barbers mouth? thou shouldest say, heavy, dull, and doltish: Melancholy is the Crest of Courtiers Arms, and now every base companion, being in his mumble fumbles, says he is melancholy.

sp.speaker: Petul.
sp.p: Motto, thou shouldest say thou art lumpish. If thou encroach upon our Courtly terms, we will trounce thee: belike if thou shouldest spit often, thou wouldst call it rheum. Motto, in men of reputation and credit it is the rheum; in such mechanical mushrumps, it is a Catarrh, a Pose, the Water evil. You were best were a velvet patch on your temples too.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.p: What a World it is to see Eggs forwarder than Cocks? these Infants are as cunning in diseases, as I that have run them over all, backward and forward. I tell you boys, it is melancholy that now troubleth me.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: My Master could tickle you with diseases, and that old ones, that have continued in his Ancestors bones these three hundred years. He is the last of the Family that is left uneaten.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: What meanest thou Dello?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: He means you are the last of the Stock alive, the rest the Worms have eaten.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: A pox of those saucy Worms, that eat men before they be dead.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: But tell us Motto why art thou sad?

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: Because all the Court is sad.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Why are they sad in Court?

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: Because the King hath a pain in his ears.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Belike it is the Wennes.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: It may be, for his ears are swollen very big.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Ten to one Motto knows of the Asses ears.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p: If he know it, we shall: for it is as hard for a Barber to keep a secret in his mouth, as a burning coal in his hand. Thou shalt see me wring it out by wit. Motto it was told me that the King will discharge you of your Office, because you cut his ear when you last trimmed him.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: It is a lie; and yet if I had, he might well spare an inch or two.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It will out, I feel him coming.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Master, take heed, you will blab all anon, these Wags are crafty.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Why Motto, what difference between the Kings ears, and thine?

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: As much as between an Asses ears and mine.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O, Motto is modest; to mitigate the matter, he calls his own ears, Asses ears.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: Nay, I mean the Kings are Asses ears.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Treason, treason!

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: I told your Master, you have made a fair hand; for now you have made your lips Scissors to cut off your ears.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: Perij, unless you pity me, Motto is in a pit.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Nay Motto, treason is a worse pain than toothache.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Now Motto, thou knowest thine ears are ours to command.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: Your servants, or handmaids.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Then will I lead my maid by the hand.

div2.stage: He pulls him by the eares.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: Out Villain, thou wringest too hard.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Not so hard as he bit me.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.p: Thou seest boy we are both mortal. I enjoy mine ears, but durante placito; nor thou thy finger, but fauente dento.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yea Motto, hast thou Latin?

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: Alas, he that hath drawn so many teeth, and never asked Latin for a tooth, is ill brought up .

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Well Motto, let us have the beard, without covin, fraud, or delay, at one entire payment, and thou shalt scape a payment.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.p: I protest by Scissors, Brush and Comb, Basin, Ball and Apron, by Razor, Ear-pike and rubbing clothes, and all the tria sequuntur triaes in our secret occupation (for you know it is no blabbing art) that you shall have the beard, in manner and form following. Not only the golden beard and every hair, (though it be not hair) but a dozen of beards, to stuff two dozen of Cushions.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Then they be big ones.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l:
They be half a yard broad, and a nail, three quarters long, and a foot thick; so sir shall you
find them stuffed enough, and soft enough. All my Mistress lines that she dries her clothes on, are made only of Moustache stuff. And if I durst tell the truth, as lusty as I am here, I lie upon a bed of beards; abbots of their bristles, and they that owe them, they are harder than flocks.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A fine discourse: well Motto, we give thee mercy, but we will not lose the beard. Remember now our Inventory. Item, we will not let thee go out of our hands, till we have the beard in our hands.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: Then follow.

sp.speaker: Myd.
sp.l: This is Delphos. Sacred Apollo, whose Oracles be all divine, though doubtful: answer poor Mydas, and pity him.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I marvel there is no answer.

sp.speaker: Myd.
sp.p: Fond Mydas, how canst thou ask pity of him whom thou hast so much abused; or why dost thou abuse the World, both to seem ignorant in not acknowledging an offence; and impudent, so openly to crave pardon. Apollo will not answer, but Mydas must not cease. Apollo, divine Apollo, Mydas hath Asses ears, yet let pity sink into thine ears, and tell when he shall be free from this shame, or what may mitigate his sin?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Tush, Apollo is tuning his pipes, or at Barley-break with Daphne, or assaying on some shepherds coat, or taking measure of a Serpents skin. Were I Mydas, I would rather cut these ears off close from my head, than stand whimpering before such a blind God.

sp.speaker: Myd.
sp.p:
Thou art barbarous not valiant. Gods must be
entreated not commanded: thou wouldst quench fire with a Sword, and add to my shame (which is more than any Prince can endure) thy rudeness, (which is more than any sensible creature would follow.) Divine Apollo what shall become of Mydas? Accept this Lute, these berries, these simples, these tapers; if Apollo take any delight in Music, in Daphne, in Physic, in eternity.

sp.l: When Pan Apollo in Music shall excel,
Mydas of Phrygia shall lose his Asses ears;
Pan did Apollo in Music far excel,
Therefore King Mydas weareth Asses ears:
Unless he shrink his stretching hand from Lesbos
His ears in length, at length shall reach to Delphos

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: It were good to expound these Oracles, that the learned men in Phrygia were assembled, otherwise the remedy will be as impossible to be had, as the cause to be sifted.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I foresaw some old saw, which should be doubtful. Who would gad to such Gods, that must be honoured if they speak without sense: and the Oracle wondered at, as though it were above sense?

sp.speaker: Myd.
sp.p:
No more Martius, I am the learnedest in Phrygia to interpret these Oracles, and though shame hath hitherto caused me to conceal it, now I must unfold it by necessity. Thus destiny bringeth me, not only to be cause of all my shame, but reporter. Thou Sophrania, and you my Lords, hearken; When I had bathed myself in Pactolus, and saw my wish to float in the waves, I wished the waves to overflow my body, so melancholy my fortune made me, so mad my folly: yet by hunting I thought to ease my heart. And coming at last to the hill Tmolus, I perceived Apollo and Pan and contending for excellency in Music: among Nymphs they required also my judgment. I (whom the loss of Gold made discontent, and the possessing desperate) either
dulled with the humours of my weak brain, or deceived by thickness of my deaf ears, preferred the harsh noise of Pans Pipe, before the sweet stroke of Apollos Lute, which caused Phoebus in justice (as I now confess, and then as I saw in anger) to set these ears on my head, that have wrung so many tears from mine eyes. For stretching my hands to Lesbos, I find that all the Gods have spurned at my practices, and those Islands scorned them. My pride the Gods disdain; my policy men: my mines have been emptied by Soldiers, my Soldiers spoiled by Wars, my Wars without success, because usurping, my usurping without end, because my ambition above measure. I will therefore yield myself to Bacchus, and acknowledge my wish to be vanity, to Apollo, and confess my judgment to be foolish: to Mars, and say my Wars are unjust: to Diana, and tell my affection hath been unnatural. And I doubt not, what a God hath done to make me know myself, all the Gods will help to undo, that I may come to myself .

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Is it possible that Mydas should be so overshot in judgment? Unhappy Mydas, whose wits melt with his Gold, and whose Gold is consumed with his wits.

sp.speaker: Myd.
sp.l: What talketh Sophronia to herself?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Nothing, but that since Mydas hath confessed his fault to us, he also acknowledge it to Apollo.

sp.speaker: Myd.
sp.p: I will Sophronia. Sacred Apollo, things passed cannot be recalled, repented they may be: behold, Mydas not only submitting himself to punishment, but confessing his peevishness, being glad for shame to call that peevishness, which indeed was folly. Whatsoever Apollo shall command, Mydas will execute.

sp.speaker: Apollo.
sp.p:
Then attend Mydas. I accept thy submission, and sacrifice, so as yearly at this Temple thou offer
Sacrifice in submission: withal, take Apollos counsel, which if thou scorn, thou shalt find thy destiny. I will not speak in riddles, all shall be plain, because thou art dull, but all certain, if thou be obstinate.
sp.l: Weigh not in one balance Gold and Justice,
With one hand wage not War and Peace.
Let thy head be glad of one Crown.
And take care to keep one friend.
The friend that thou wouldst make thy foe.
The Kingdom thou wouldst make the World
The hand that thou dost arm with force.
The Gold that thou dost think a God
Shall conquer, fall, shrink short, be common:
With force, with pride, with fear, with Traffic.
If this thou like shake off an Asses ears:
If not for ever shake an Asses ears.
Apollo will not reply

sp.speaker: Myd.
sp.p: It may be Sophronia, that neither you, nor any else, understand Apollo, because none of you have the heart of a King: but my thoughts expound my fortunes, and my fortunes hang upon my thoughts. That great Apollo, that joined to my head Asses cares, hath put into my heart a Lions mind. I see that by obscure shadows, which you cannot discern in fresh colours. Apollo in the depth of his dark answer, is to me the glistering of a bright Sun. I perceive (and yet not too late) that Lesbos will not be touched by gold, by force it cannot: that the Gods have pitched it out of the World, as not to be controlled by any in the World. Though my hand be gold, yet I must not think to span over the main Ocean. Though my Soldiers be valiant, I must not therefore think my quarrels just. There is no way to nail the Crown of Phrygia fast to my daughters head, but in letting the crowns of others sit in quiet on theirs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mydas?

sp.speaker: Myd.
sp.p: How darest thou reply seeing me resolved? thy counsel hath spilt more blood than all my Soldiers Lances, let none be so hardy as to look to cross me. Sacred Apollo, if sacrifice yearly at thy temple, and submission hourly in mine own Court, if fulfilling thy counsel, and correcting my Councillors may shake off these Asses ears, I here before thee vow to shake off all envies abroad, and at home all tyranny.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Honoured be Apollo, Mydas is restored.

sp.speaker: Myd.
sp.l: Fortunate Mydas, that feelest thy head lightened of dull ears, and thy heart of deadly sorrows. Come my Lords, let us repair to our Palace, in which Apollo shall have a stately Statue erected: every month will we solemnise there a Feast, and here every year a Sacrifice. Phrygia shall be governed by Gods, not men, lest the Gods make beasts of men. So my Counsel of War shall not make conquests in their own conceits, nor my Councillors in peace make me poor, to enrich themselves. So blessed be Apollo, quiet be Lesbos, happy be Mydas: and to begin this solemnity, let us sing to Apollo, for, so much as Music, nothing can content Apollo.

sp.speaker: Myd.
sp.l: Sing to Apollo God of Day,
Whose golden beams with morning play,
And make her eyes so brightly shine,
Aurora's face is called Divine.
Sing to Phoebus and that Throne
Of Diamonds which he sits upon;
I Pans let us sing,
To Physics, and to Poesies King.
Crown all his Altars with bright fire,
Laurels bind about his Lire,
A Daphnean Coronet for his Head,
The Muses dance about his Bed,
When on his ravishing Lute he plays,
Strew his Temple round with Bays,
I Pans let us sing,
To the glittering Delian King.
